acts.title: The Solid State Revolution
acts.description: From Bell Labs to Silicon Valley, trace the invention of the transistor and the integrated circuit‚Äîthe discoveries that made modern computing possible. Every vacuum tube that burned out, every unreliable connection, every room-sized computer drove engineers toward a singular goal: solid-state switching.

setting.text: Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, New Jersey. December 1947. Snow blankets the manicured grounds of the research campus. Inside Building 1, the solid-state physics group is racing toward a breakthrough that will change history.

narrative: The telephone network is failing. Every switching station depends on vacuum tubes‚Äîhot, fragile, power-hungry tubes that burn out constantly. AT&T's continental network uses millions of them.
Somewhere, right now, a tube is failing. A call is dropping. A customer is complaining.

You've been assigned to William Shockley's solid-state physics group. The mandate is clear: find a replacement for the vacuum tube. Something solid. Something reliable. Something that doesn't burn out.

characters.name: William Shockley
characters.title: Group Leader, Solid-State Physics
characters.bio: Brilliant, ambitious, and difficult. Shockley leads the team with an iron will. His theoretical work on semiconductors is groundbreaking, but his personality alienates colleagues. He believes solid-state amplification is possible‚Äîhe just can't make it work.

technicalNotes.content: Vacuum tubes work by 'thermionic emission'‚Äîheating a metal cathode until electrons boil off, then controlling their flow with a grid. This requires a vacuum, high voltages, and significant power. A typical tube consumes 5-10 watts just to stay warm.

setting.text: Shockley's laboratory. Benches cluttered with oscilloscopes, spectrometers, and chunks of germanium crystal. The air smells of solder and frustration.

narrative: Shockley's idea is elegant: use an electric field to control current flow through a semiconductor, just as the grid controls electron flow in a tube. He calls it the 'field-effect' approach.
The theory is sound. The math works out. But every experiment fails.
Something is blocking the field effect. The semiconductor surface seems to 'trap' charges, screening the external field. No one understands why.

characters.name: John Bardeen
characters.title: Theoretical Physicist
characters.bio: Quiet, methodical, brilliant. Bardeen approaches problems with patient persistence. While Shockley demands results, Bardeen asks why the experiments fail. His surface-state theory will unlock the mystery.

stats.label: Future
stats.value: Only person to win 2 Nobel Prizes in Physics

characters.name: Walter Brattain
characters.title: Experimental Physicist
characters.bio: Hands-on genius. If Bardeen is the mind, Brattain is the hands. He builds the experiments, improvises solutions, and notices the anomalies that lead to breakthroughs. Practical to the core.

dialogues.speaker: Shockley
dialogues.text: The field effect should work. The mathematics is clear. Why does the experiment fail?

dialogues.speaker: Bardeen
dialogues.text: The surface. Charges are getting trapped at the semiconductor surface. They're screening your external field before it can penetrate.

dialogues.speaker: Shockley
dialogues.text: Then find a way around the surface.

setting.text: November 17, 1947. Brattain is running yet another failed experiment when he notices something unexpected.

narrative: The germanium sample sits in a water droplet‚Äîan accident, really. Brattain dips his probe into the electrolyte and... the signal amplifies.
Water? Why would water matter?
The electrolyte is neutralizing the surface charges. For the first time, the field effect works‚Äîweakly, erratically, but it works.
Bardeen realizes: if water can modify the surface, perhaps a different approach can too. What if instead of fighting the surface, they worked through it?

technicalNotes.content: The surface-state problem plagued semiconductor research for years. Bardeen's insight was that electrons get trapped in 'dangling bonds' at the crystal surface, creating a barrier to field effects. This understanding eventually led to the MOS transistor‚Äîwhich uses a thin oxide layer to control surface states.

dialogues.speaker: Brattain
dialogues.text: John, come look at this. The water did something. I'm getting amplification‚Äîsmall, but real.

setting.text: December 16, 1947. The laboratory is tense. Brattain has a new design: two gold contacts pressed into germanium, incredibly close together. If this works...

narrative: Brattain's design bypasses the surface problem entirely. Instead of using a field through the surface, he injects current directly through one contact (the emitter) and modulates it with a second contact (the collector).
It's not Shockley's elegant field-effect design. It's a hack, really. But if it amplifies...

choices.title: Observe the Experiment
choices.description: Watch Brattain and Bardeen make history. See the moment the first transistor amplifies a signal.

choices.title: Understand the Theory
choices.description: Have Bardeen explain why the point-contact approach works where the field effect failed.

choices.title: Roads Not Taken: Lilienfeld's FET
choices.description: In 1926, Julius Lilienfeld patented the field-effect transistor. It should have worked. Return to your lab and build what he envisioned.

setting.text: The laboratory bench. December 16, 1947. Brattain's hands are steady as he positions the gold contacts.

narrative: You stand behind Brattain as he prepares the apparatus. A wedge of plastic, gold foil slit with a razor blade to create two contacts separated by a hair's breadth. A piece of germanium crystal.
Brattain lowers the contacts onto the crystal. The oscilloscope trace flickers. He adjusts the bias voltages‚Äînegative on one contact, positive on the other.
Then he applies a signal to the emitter contact. On the oscilloscope, the collector signal jumps‚Äîamplified. Not attenuated. Amplified.

dialogues.speaker: Brattain
dialogues.text: John! Look at this gain! We're getting voltage amplification. Current gain too. It's working, John. It's really working.

dialogues.speaker: Bardeen
dialogues.text: Power gain greater than unity. That's the definition of amplification. We've done it.

dialogues.speaker: Brattain
dialogues.text: All those months of failed experiments... and it comes down to this ugly little wedge of plastic and gold.

technicalNotes.content: The first transistor achieved a power gain of 18‚Äîmeaning the output power was 18 times the input power. The critical parameter was the 50-micrometer spacing between contacts. Closer spacing meant more gain but was nearly impossible to achieve with 1947 fabrication techniques.

setting.text: Bardeen's small office. Chalkboards covered with equations. A few germanium samples on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: Why did the point-contact approach work when the field effect failed?

dialogues.speaker: Bardeen
dialogues.text: The field effect tries to control current by pushing charges around with an electric field. But surface states trap those charges‚Äîthey screen the field before it can penetrate the semiconductor.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: And point contact avoids that?

dialogues.speaker: Bardeen
dialogues.text: Point contact injects minority carriers directly into the bulk. The emitter contact pushes holes into n-type germanium. Those holes diffuse through the crystal to the collector. Surface states can't screen what's happening inside the bulk.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: So it's a completely different mechanism?

dialogues.speaker: Bardeen
dialogues.text: Yes. Shockley's field effect modulates the surface. Our point contact modulates the bulk. Both are valid approaches‚Äîbut only one works with today's materials. Someday, when we can control surface states, the field effect will have its day.

technicalNotes.content: Bardeen was right: the field-effect transistor (FET) eventually dominated. The MOSFET, using a thin oxide layer to control surface states, was invented in 1959. Today, virtually all digital circuits use MOSFETs‚ÄîShockley's original concept, finally realized.

setting.text: A historical detour: your workbench, reconfigured for 1926 technology.

narrative: Julius Edgar Lilienfeld filed his FET patent in 1926‚Äîtwenty years before Bardeen and Brattain. His design was sound: a thin semiconductor film with a metal gate to control conductivity.
Why didn't it work? Materials. Lilienfeld's semiconductors were impure, his surfaces uncontrolled. The physics was right; the fabrication wasn't.
You have an advantage: hindsight. Build Lilienfeld's FET with modern understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Historical Note
dialogues.text: Lilienfeld's 1926 patent describes a field-effect device remarkably similar to modern MOSFETs. He even suggested using thin oxide films. But without pure semiconductors and clean surfaces, no one could make it work for thirty more years.

technicalNotes.content: Lilienfeld's patent (US 1,745,175) describes a 'Method and apparatus for controlling electric currents' using semiconductor thin films. The patent was granted but never successfully demonstrated. Semiconductor purity technology didn't exist until the 1940s, and surface passivation wasn't understood until Bardeen's work.

setting.text: December 23, 1947. The moment that changed computing forever.

narrative: Brattain's apparatus looks almost comical: a triangle of plastic with gold foil contacts, pressed against a slab of germanium. A paper clip holds it in place.
But when current flows through the emitter contact, something miraculous happens: the collector current is amplified. A small signal in, a large signal out.
Solid-state amplification. No vacuum. No heated cathode. No moving parts.

objectives.text: Create a germanium base with proper doping
Position emitter and collector contacts (<50Œºm apart)
Apply bias voltages for amplification mode

technicalNotes.content: The point-contact transistor worked by 'minority carrier injection.' The emitter contact injected holes into the n-type germanium base. These holes diffused to the collector contact, modulating its current. Gain depended on the geometry‚Äîcontacts had to be incredibly close.

setting.text: The oscilloscope trace shows unmistakable amplification. Bardeen and Brattain look at each other in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Brattain
dialogues.text: John... it's working. We're getting gain. Real gain.

dialogues.speaker: Bardeen
dialogues.text: This changes everything. Solid-state amplification. No tubes. No vacuum.

dialogues.speaker: Brattain
dialogues.text: Should we tell Shockley?

dialogues.speaker: Bardeen
dialogues.text: We have to. But... this isn't his field-effect design. This is something different. He won't be happy.

narrative: Shockley's reaction was complex. Pride in his team. Fury that he wasn't involved in the final breakthrough. Determination to find a better design.
Within weeks, Shockley invented the junction transistor‚Äîa more practical design that would dominate the industry. But the Nobel Prize would go to all three: Shockley, Bardeen, and Brattain.
The vacuum tube's days were numbered. The solid-state revolution had begun.

setting.text: Texas Instruments, Dallas, Texas. Summer 1958. The semiconductor industry is booming‚Äîand struggling. Transistors work, but complex circuits require thousands of hand-soldered connections.

narrative: Jack Kilby is new at TI, with no accrued vacation time. While everyone else enjoys summer break, he sits alone in the lab, thinking.
The problem haunts him: every complex circuit is a reliability nightmare. A thousand transistors mean a thousand connections. Every solder joint is a failure waiting to happen.
They call it the 'Tyranny of Numbers.' The more capable the system, the less reliable it becomes.

characters.name: Jack Kilby
characters.title: Engineer, Texas Instruments
characters.bio: A practical engineer with a radical idea. While others try to improve manufacturing, Kilby asks: what if we eliminate connections entirely? What if the entire circuit is one piece of semiconductor?

technicalNotes.content: By 1958, transistor manufacturing was mature. But complex systems still required hand assembly. The IBM 7090 computer used ~50,000 transistors‚Äîeach one hand-soldered to its neighbors. Assembly dominated system cost.

setting.text: July 1958. Kilby's notebook fills with sketches. An insane idea is taking shape.

narrative: Kilby's insight: semiconductors can make everything. Transistors, obviously. But also resistors‚Äîa strip of doped semiconductor has resistance. And capacitors‚Äîa reverse-biased p-n junction acts like a capacitor.
What if the entire circuit was built from one piece of semiconductor? No wires. No solder. One monolithic block with all the components built in.

dialogues.speaker: Kilby
dialogues.text: The semiconductor can do it all. Transistors for switching. Resistors from the substrate. Capacitors from the junctions. We don't need separate parts‚Äîwe need one part that does everything.

technicalNotes.content: Kilby's key insight: semiconductors can form resistors (doped regions), capacitors (junction capacitance), and transistors (multiple junctions) all in the same material. 'Monolithic' literally means 'one stone'‚Äîa single piece of semiconductor containing an entire circuit.

setting.text: Meanwhile, at Fairchild Semiconductor in California, a different team approaches the same problem.

narrative: Robert Noyce never heard of Kilby's work. But he's solving the same problem from a different angle.
Fairchild has a secret weapon: the planar process, invented by Jean Hoerni. It grows a protective oxide layer over the silicon surface, allowing precise, reproducible transistors.
Noyce realizes: that oxide layer could also insulate metal interconnects. Wire the components together with aluminum traces on top of the chip, insulated by oxide. No wire bonds. No hand assembly.

characters.name: Robert Noyce
characters.title: Co-founder, Fairchild Semiconductor
characters.bio: Charismatic, visionary, entrepreneurial. Noyce co-founded Fairchild after leaving Shockley's toxic workplace. His planar IC design will prove more practical than Kilby's, leading to modern chip fabrication.

characters.name: Jean Hoerni
characters.title: Physicist, Fairchild
characters.bio: Swiss physicist who invented the planar process‚Äîgrowing silicon dioxide on silicon to protect and passivate transistors. This seemingly minor innovation made modern chip manufacturing possible.

technicalNotes.content: The planar process was revolutionary: growing a thin layer of silicon dioxide (glass) on silicon. This oxide passivates the surface (solving the surface-state problem!), protects the transistor, and‚Äîcrucially‚Äîprovides insulation for metal interconnects. All modern chips use variations of this process.

setting.text: September 12, 1958. Kilby demonstrates the first integrated circuit at TI. It's crude‚Äîhand-wired connections‚Äîbut it works.

narrative: Kilby's IC is a phase-shift oscillator: transistor, resistors, capacitors, all in one piece of germanium. Gold wires still connect the components‚Äîthe monolithic vision isn't complete yet.
Six months later, Noyce files a patent for the planar integrated circuit: truly monolithic, with aluminum traces deposited directly on the chip.
Both approaches work. Both change history. The patent fight will last decades.

choices.title: Study Kilby's Approach
choices.description: Examine the first IC: germanium substrate, wire-bonded connections, proof of concept.

choices.title: Study Noyce's Approach
choices.description: Examine the planar IC: silicon substrate, oxide isolation, aluminum interconnects.

choices.title: Build Your Own IC
choices.description: Enter the lab and design an integrated circuit combining multiple components on one chip.

setting.text: Texas Instruments laboratory. Kilby's first integrated circuit sits under a microscope.

narrative: The IC looks almost primitive: a sliver of germanium about half an inch long, with tiny gold wires bonded to various points. It's a phase-shift oscillator‚Äîtransistor, capacitors, and resistors all in one piece of semiconductor.
Kilby points to the components. 'The transistor is here‚Äîa mesa structure etched into the surface. The resistors are these doped regions. The capacitors use junction capacitance.'
The wires bother you. 'I thought the point was to eliminate connections?'

dialogues.speaker: Kilby
dialogues.text: These wires are temporary. They connect the components because I haven't figured out how to make interconnects in the semiconductor itself. But the principle is proven: all the components can be made from one piece of material.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: Why germanium? Fairchild uses silicon.

dialogues.speaker: Kilby
dialogues.text: TI knows germanium. We have the processes, the equipment, the expertise. Silicon is harder to work with‚Äîhigher temperatures, more demanding chemistry. But I suspect silicon will win in the end. It's more abundant, and silicon dioxide is a natural insulator.

technicalNotes.content: Kilby's first IC (September 12, 1958) used germanium and required external wire bonds between components. It proved the monolithic concept but wasn't practical for manufacturing. Kilby received the 2000 Nobel Prize in Physics for inventing the IC.

setting.text: Fairchild Semiconductor, Mountain View. The planar IC gleams under harsh fluorescent lights.

narrative: Noyce's IC looks different from Kilby's. The surface is flat‚Äîplanar‚Äîcovered with a glassy layer of silicon dioxide. Aluminum traces snake across the surface, connecting components beneath.
It's beautiful in its simplicity. No wire bonds. No exposed junctions. Everything protected by oxide, connected by metal.
Jean Hoerni's planar process made this possible. Grow oxide, etch windows, diffuse dopants, deposit metal. Layer by layer, the circuit takes shape.

dialogues.speaker: Noyce
dialogues.text: The oxide does everything. It masks during diffusion. It passivates the surface. It insulates the interconnects. Silicon dioxide is the secret ingredient.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: Why didn't Kilby do this?

dialogues.speaker: Noyce
dialogues.text: Germanium doesn't form a good native oxide. Silicon does. That's why silicon wins‚Äînot because of the transistors themselves, but because of the oxide. SiO2 is a near-perfect insulator that grows naturally on silicon.

technicalNotes.content: Noyce's planar IC (January 1959) used silicon and integrated metal interconnects‚Äîno wire bonds. The planar process became the foundation of all modern IC fabrication. Noyce didn't receive a Nobel Prize (he died in 1990; the prize cannot be awarded posthumously), but he's often called 'the Mayor of Silicon Valley.'

setting.text: Your workbench awaits. The tools of IC fabrication are ready: silicon wafers, dopant gases, photolithography masks, oxide furnaces.

narrative: Design a simple integrated circuit: an inverter (NOT gate) followed by a buffer. Two transistors, load resistors, all on one chip.
This humble circuit is the ancestor of the billions of transistors in modern processors.

technicalNotes.content: IC fabrication is a layer-by-layer process: grow oxide, etch windows, diffuse dopants, deposit metal, etch patterns. Each layer is defined by a 'mask'‚Äîa pattern projected onto photoresist. Modern chips have 50+ layers; early ICs had 3-4.

setting.text: Your IC works. Two transistors, integrated on silicon. The oscilloscope shows clean digital transitions.

dialogues.speaker: Noyce
dialogues.text: You see the potential? Today, two transistors. Tomorrow, twenty. Next year, two hundred. There's no limit‚Äîexcept what we can pattern and connect.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: How many transistors could we eventually fit on a chip?

dialogues.speaker: Noyce
dialogues.text: Gordon Moore has been tracking this. He thinks the count will double every year or two. At that rate... millions within our lifetime.

narrative: Moore's prediction would prove remarkably accurate. The 'law' bearing his name guided the industry for fifty years: transistor counts doubling roughly every two years.
But ICs needed a market to drive that growth. They were expensive, unproven, and most engineers didn't trust them.
That market would come from an unexpected source: the race to the moon.

setting.text: MIT Instrumentation Laboratory, Cambridge, Massachusetts. 1965. President Kennedy's challenge echoes: land a man on the moon and return him safely before the decade is out.

narrative: The Apollo spacecraft needs an onboard computer. Not a room-sized machine‚Äîa computer that fits in a one-cubic-foot box, weighs less than 70 pounds, and survives the violence of rocket launch.
And it must not fail. Astronauts' lives depend on it.
The only possible technology: integrated circuits. But ICs are new, expensive, and unproven. Can they be trusted with human lives?

characters.name: Eldon Hall
characters.title: Lead Designer, Apollo Guidance Computer
characters.bio: MIT engineer tasked with the impossible: fit a computer into a spacecraft. Hall championed ICs when everyone else wanted proven technology. His bet paid off‚Äîand accelerated the entire semiconductor industry.

technicalNotes.content: The Apollo Guidance Computer used 4,100 ICs‚Äîeach a simple 3-input NOR gate. By buying 60% of all ICs produced in 1963, NASA drove prices from $1,000/chip to $25/chip and forced manufacturers to improve reliability.

setting.text: The IC qualification lab. Every chip must be tested, burned in, and verified before it can fly.

narrative: You're assigned to the reliability team. Your job: ensure that every IC meets space-grade quality. Temperature cycling. Vibration testing. Radiation exposure.
The Fairchild chips arrive in batches. Some pass. Many fail. The ones that pass go through burn-in: running at elevated temperature for weeks to weed out 'infant mortality' failures.
Only the survivors fly to the moon.

characters.name: Margaret Hamilton
characters.title: Director, Software Engineering
characters.bio: Leading the software team, Hamilton coins the term 'software engineering' to give her discipline credibility. Her code will save Apollo 11 when hardware overloads threaten the landing.

technicalNotes.content: IC reliability follows a 'bathtub curve': high initial failure rate (infant mortality), then low stable rate, then increasing failures (wear-out). Burn-in eliminates infant mortality by running chips at elevated stress, forcing weak units to fail before deployment.

setting.text: Your reliability lab workbench. A tray of ICs awaits qualification testing.

narrative: The AGC uses 3-input NOR gates exclusively. Every Boolean function‚ÄîAND, OR, NOT, memory‚Äîis built from NOR gates.
Design and verify a NOR gate's reliability. Then build a simple AGC circuit: an inverter chain using only NOR gates.

objectives.text: Understand NOR gate logic (output = NOT(A OR B OR C))
Build NOT gate from NOR (tie inputs together)
Build AND gate from NOR gates
Build OR gate from NOR gates
Design a 4-bit register using NOR-based flip-flops

technicalNotes.content: NOR gates are 'universal'‚Äîany Boolean function can be built from NOR gates alone. Using a single gate type simplified manufacturing and testing. The AGC designers chose NOR over NAND for electrical reasons (easier level shifting).

setting.text: July 20, 1969. The Eagle lunar module descends toward the Sea of Tranquility. Alarms blare in Mission Control.

dialogues.speaker: Mission Control
dialogues.text: Eagle, we're seeing a 1202 alarm. What's your status?

dialogues.speaker: Buzz Aldrin
dialogues.text: Give us the reading on the 1202 program alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Mission Control
dialogues.text: Roger, we got you. We're GO on that alarm.

narrative: The 1202 alarm: executive overflow. The computer is overloaded‚Äîthe rendezvous radar is flooding it with data it doesn't need for landing.
But Margaret Hamilton's software has priority scheduling. Non-essential tasks are shed. The landing program keeps running.
The computer you helped qualify is about to land humans on another world.

technicalNotes.content: The 1202/1201 alarms during Apollo 11 descent were caused by a hardware design issue: the rendezvous radar fed spurious signals to the computer. Hamilton's priority-based executive software shed low-priority tasks and kept the landing program running. Without this 'asynchronous executive,' the landing would have been aborted.

setting.text: The Eagle lands. Armstrong's words echo across 240,000 miles: 'Houston, Tranquility Base here. The Eagle has landed.'

narrative: Integrated circuits, tested and qualified to survive space, have guided humans to the moon and back.
NASA's investment paid off beyond measure. The price of ICs dropped 98%. Reliability improved a thousandfold. An industry that served a handful of military customers now serves the world.
The semiconductor revolution is real. The only question now: what comes next?

setting.text: Intel Corporation, Santa Clara, California. 1969. A Japanese calculator company has a problem: they need a new brain for their desktop calculator, and they need it fast.

narrative: Busicom's calculator design requires twelve custom chips. Twelve different integrated circuits, each designed from scratch, each requiring masks, testing, qualification.
Intel is a memory company‚Äîthey make RAM and ROM chips. Custom calculator logic isn't their specialty. But the contract is lucrative, and Intel is young and hungry.

characters.name: Ted Hoff
characters.title: Engineer, Intel
characters.bio: Stanford-trained engineer who looked at Busicom's 12-chip design and asked: what if there was a simpler way? His insight‚Äîa general-purpose processor programmed with software‚Äîwill create the microprocessor industry.

technicalNotes.content: Busicom's original design used specialized logic: one chip for keyboard scanning, one for display driving, one for addition, one for multiplication, etc. Each function was hardwired in silicon. Changes required new masks‚Äîexpensive and slow.

setting.text: Ted Hoff studies the Busicom specification. Something bothers him: most of the complexity is doing the same things over and over in slightly different ways.

narrative: "What if," Hoff muses, "instead of twelve specialized chips, we made one general-purpose chip? A tiny computer that could be programmed to do any of these tasks."
The idea is radical. Calculators use hardwired logic because software is slow. But if the chip is fast enough, and the architecture clever enough...

Hoff sketches a design: a 4-bit CPU with a small instruction set, paired with ROM (for the program) and RAM (for data). Three chips instead of twelve‚Äîand the same three chips could be reprogrammed for different calculators.

characters.name: Federico Faggin
characters.title: Engineer, Intel
characters.bio: Italian-born chip designer who will turn Hoff's concept into working silicon. Faggin's mastery of circuit design and fabrication makes the impossible possible: a complete CPU in 2,300 transistors.

characters.name: Masatoshi Shima
characters.title: Engineer, Busicom
characters.bio: Busicom's representative at Intel, initially skeptical of Hoff's simplified design. Shima pushed back on the spec, forcing refinements that made the 4004 more capable.

dialogues.speaker: Hoff
dialogues.text: We don't need twelve chips. We need one chip that can be taught to do twelve things.

dialogues.speaker: Shima
dialogues.text: A programmable chip? For a calculator? The performance...

dialogues.speaker: Hoff
dialogues.text: Will be fast enough. Trust me. The simplicity gains outweigh the speed loss.

setting.text: November 1971. The Intel 4004 is ready for announcement. The world's first commercial microprocessor.

narrative: Four chips total: the 4004 CPU, 4001 ROM, 4002 RAM, and 4003 shift register. Together, they form the MCS-4 system‚Äîa computer on a handful of chips.
The 4004 runs at 740 kHz. It has 2,300 transistors. Its 4-bit architecture limits it to simple calculations. But it's a complete CPU‚Äîfetch, decode, execute, repeat.
And it can be programmed. Change the software, change the machine.

choices.title: Study the Architecture
choices.description: Examine the 4004's instruction set, registers, and memory addressing. Understand the first microprocessor.

choices.title: Enter the Lab
choices.description: It's time. Build your own 4-bit microprocessor based on the 4004's architecture. This is the Micro4.

choices.title: Roads Not Taken: Datapoint 2200
choices.description: Intel almost built a different processor first‚Äîthe 8008 for Datapoint. What if that design had come first?

setting.text: A technical deep-dive into the world's first microprocessor.

narrative: The 4004 is a marvel of miniaturization: 2,300 transistors in a 3mm √ó 4mm die. Faggin drew every transistor by hand, at 500√ó magnification, on rubylith film.

The architecture reflects its calculator origins. Sixteen 4-bit registers serve as scratchpad memory. A single accumulator handles arithmetic. The ALU performs binary-coded decimal (BCD) operations‚Äîbecause calculators display decimal digits.
Forty-six instructions cover arithmetic, logic, register manipulation, and program control. A three-level hardware stack enables subroutine calls.

dialogues.speaker: Faggin
dialogues.text: Every transistor had to be placed by hand. I worked 80-hour weeks for months. The 4004 is as much art as engineering‚Äîevery micron matters.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: Why only 4 bits? That seems limiting.

dialogues.speaker: Faggin
dialogues.text: BCD digits are 4 bits. For a calculator, 4 bits is exactly right. But you're correct‚Äîgeneral computing needs more. The 8008 is already in design: 8-bit data, larger address space. Then 16-bit, then 32...

technicalNotes.content: The 4004's instruction set was optimized for BCD arithmetic. The DAA (Decimal Adjust Accumulator) instruction corrects binary addition to produce valid BCD results. Modern x86 processors still include this instruction for backward compatibility‚Äîa relic of the calculator era.

setting.text: An alternate history: what if the 8008 had come first?

narrative: Intel actually started the 8008 design before the 4004. Datapoint Corporation wanted a CPU for their 2200 programmable terminal. Victor Poor and Harry Pyle designed an 8-bit architecture that Intel agreed to implement in silicon.
But the 8008 was delayed. Datapoint needed terminals immediately, so they built the 2200 from discrete TTL chips. By the time Intel delivered the 8008 in 1972, Datapoint didn't need it anymore.

Ironically, the 8008's architecture‚Äîdesigned for a terminal‚Äîbecame the foundation of the 8080, which became the foundation of x86. Every Intel PC processor descends from a terminal controller nobody wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Historical Note
dialogues.text: The Datapoint 2200 architecture, designed by Victor Poor and Harry Pyle, specified 8-bit registers named A, B, C, D, E, H, and L. These register names survive in x86 as AX, BX, CX, DX‚Äîforty years later.

technicalNotes.content: The 8008 (1972) was the true ancestor of x86. Its 8-bit accumulator, six general registers, and stack-based subroutines defined the architecture that Intel would expand into 8080, 8086, and eventually the modern x86-64. The 4004's BCD-focused design was an evolutionary dead end.

setting.text: Your lab bench is ready. The knowledge of five millennia of computation has led to this moment: building your own CPU.

narrative: From abacus beads to vacuum tubes to transistors to integrated circuits‚Äîevery step has prepared you for this.
Build the Micro4. A 4-bit CPU with accumulator architecture, like the 4004. Fetch instructions from memory. Decode them. Execute them. Repeat.
This is where the Digital Archaeology journey truly begins.

objectives.text: Design the ALU: 4-bit addition with carry
Execute a simple program: add two numbers

technicalNotes.content: The Intel 4004 had: 4-bit data bus, 16 registers (as scratchpad), 12-bit addresses (4KB), 46 instructions, and 3-level hardware stack. The Micro4 simplifies this for learning while preserving the essential concepts.

setting.text: Your Micro4 executes its first program. A simple addition‚Äîbut the first step on a long journey.

dialogues.speaker: Faggin
dialogues.text: You've built a microprocessor. Do you understand what that means?

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: It's a CPU... on a chip. A programmable machine.

dialogues.speaker: Faggin
dialogues.text: More than that. It's the democratization of computing. Before this, only governments and corporations could afford computers. Now anyone can build one‚Äîwith enough knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: Hoff
dialogues.text: And we're just getting started. Four bits today. Eight bits tomorrow. Sixteen, thirty-two... The applications we can't even imagine yet.
